articles.headline: China’s Rich Try to Fly Around Red Tape
articles.snippet: With the military jealously guarding its control of the airspace, wealthy Chinese hobbyists fly clandestinely.
articles.abstract: With the military jealously guarding its control of the airspace, wealthy Chinese hobbyists fly clandestinely.
articles.lead_paragraph: WENZHOU, China — Here in this smoggy coastal metropolis, the nouveau-riche heart of entrepreneurial China, the latest sign that one has really made it is not a Benz, or even a Bentley. It is a helicopter. Perhaps 10 of Wenzhou’s super-rich have one.

articles.headline: Delta-Northwest Merger’s Long and Complex Path
articles.snippet: When Delta acquired Northwest three years ago, executives did not fully anticipate the thousands of tiny details that can make the difference between a successful merger and a failed one.
articles.abstract: When Delta acquired Northwest three years ago, executives did not fully anticipate the thousands of tiny details that can make the difference between a successful merger and a failed one.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — How many chimes should pilots ring to signal the plane is about to land — two or four? Should flight attendants first pour drinks into a cup or just hand over the can?

articles.headline: Ins and Outs of Using Gadgetry
articles.snippet: Presenting some basics of modern technology that may help any BlackBerry or PC user.
articles.abstract: Presenting some basics of modern technology that may help any BlackBerry or PC user.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every time a reader asks me a basic question, struggles with a computer or lets a cellphone keep ringing at a performance, I have the same thought: There ought to be a license to use technology.

articles.headline: Many With New College Degree Find the Job Market Humbling
articles.snippet: Employment rates for new graduates have fallen sharply, as have starting salaries for those who can find work.
articles.abstract: Employment rates for new graduates have fallen sharply, as have starting salaries for those who can find work.
articles.lead_paragraph: The individual stories are familiar. The chemistry major tending bar. The classics major answering phones. The Italian studies major sweeping aisles at Wal-Mart.

articles.headline: A Blood Test Offers Clues to Longevity
articles.snippet: Some experts say that blood tests that seek to tell people their biological age do not provide useful information.
articles.abstract: Some experts say that blood tests that seek to tell people their biological age do not provide useful information.
articles.lead_paragraph: Want to know how long you will live?

articles.headline: Focus Is on Obama as Tensions Soar Across Mideast
articles.snippet: American and Israeli officials are struggling to balance national security interests against the need to adapt to a transformative movement in the Arab world.
articles.abstract: American and Israeli officials are struggling to balance national security interests against the need to adapt to a transformative movement in the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few game-changing proposals are emerging to defuse tensions in the Middle East as a busy week of diplomacy unfolds with President Obama’s address to the region and his meeting with Israel’s prime minister.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: Private Prisons Found to Offer Little in Savings
articles.snippet: As Arizona and other states look to resolve budget problems, research suggests private prisons can cost about the same as state-run ones.
articles.abstract: As Arizona and other states look to resolve budget problems, research suggests private prisons can cost about the same as state-run ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The conviction that private prisons save money helped drive more than 30 states to turn to them for housing inmates. But Arizona shows that popular wisdom might be wrong: Data there suggest that privately operated prisons can cost more to operate than state-run prisons — even though they often steer clear of the sickest, costliest inmates.

articles.headline: Strauss-Kahn Resigns From I.M.F. in Wake of His Arrest
articles.snippet: The head of the International Monetary Fund stepped down after explosive allegations that he had sexually attacked a cleaning lady in a Manhattan hotel room.
articles.abstract: The head of the International Monetary Fund stepped down after explosive allegations that he had sexually attacked a cleaning lady in a Manhattan hotel room.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dominique Strauss-Kahn resigned Wednesday as head of the International Monetary Fund after explosive accusations that he had sexually attacked a housekeeper in a Midtown hotel room.

articles.headline: A Shaken Agency Looks to the Future
articles.snippet: Emerging-market nations like Brazil hope to brake the stranglehold Europe has had on the top job at the International Monetary Fund.
articles.abstract: Emerging-market nations like Brazil hope to brake the stranglehold Europe has had on the top job at the International Monetary Fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: European officials moved quickly to assert their claim over the leadership of the International Monetary Fund on Thursday, suggesting a serious challenge is being mounted by emerging economic powers like China and India that believe the time has come to break Europe’s historic grip on the post.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Graham Bowley
